On the way to Pleasure Island, he befriends\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Candlewick_(Pinocchio_character)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Lampwick}}, a delinquent boy. Without rules or authority to enforce their activity, Pinocchio and the other boys soon engage in\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Tobacco_smoking"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 smoking}}\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Tobacco"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 tobacco}},\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Gambling"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 gambling}},\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Vandalism"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 vandalism}}, and getting\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Drunk"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 drunk}}, much to Jiminy's dismay. Later, while trying to get home, Jiminy discovers that the island hides a horrible curse: the boys brought to Pleasure Island are transformed into\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Donkey"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 donkeys}}\'a0for their misbehavior and sold into slave labor. Jiminy runs back to warn Pinocchio, only to discover that Lampwick has transformed into a donkey; Pinocchio manages to escape, only partially transformed.\
Upon returning home, Pinocchio and Jiminy find the workshop vacant. They soon get a letter from the blue fairy as a dove, stating that Geppetto had ventured out to sea to save Pinocchio from Pleasure Island, but was swallowed by a terrible\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Sperm_whale"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 giant whale}}\'a0named\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/The_Terrible_Dogfish"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Monstro}}, and is now living in his belly. Determined to rescue his father, Pinocchio jumps into the sea accompanied by Jiminy. Pinocchio is soon swallowed by Monstro as well, where he is reunited with Geppetto. Pinocchio devises a scheme to make Monstro sneeze, giving them a chance to escape. The scheme works, but the enraged whale-monster chases them and smashes their raft. Pinocchio pulls Geppetto to safety in a cave before Monstro crashes into it. Geppetto, Figaro, Cleo, and Jiminy are washed up safely on a beach, but Pinocchio is killed.\
Back home, Geppetto grieves over Pinocchio with Jiminy Cricket and the pets also mourn alongside. The Blue Fairy, however, decides that Pinocchio has proven himself brave, truthful, and unselfish. To reward him, the Blue Fairy resurrects Pinocchio, reversing the Pleasure Island curse and turning him into a real boy. Pinocchio awakens and reveals that he is alive and a real human boy, and everyone celebrates. Jiminy steps outside to thank the Fairy, and is rewarded with a solid gold badge that certifies him as an official conscience.\
"Big John" McMasters ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Clark_Gable"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Clark Gable}}) and "Square John" Sand ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Spencer_Tracy"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Spencer Tracy}}) are two down-on-their-luck oil\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Wildcatter"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 wildcatters}}\'a0who join forces. Without enough money, they steal drilling equipment from a skeptical Luther Aldrich ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Frank_Morgan"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Frank Morgan}}). Their well proves a bust and they have to hastily depart when Aldrich shows up with the sheriff to take back his property. The two oilmen team up and make enough money to partially pay Aldrich. To get him to back them for a second try, they cut him in for a percentage of the well. This time, they strike it rich.\
When Elizabeth 'Betsy' Bartlett ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Claudette_Colbert"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Claudette Colbert}}) shows up, McMasters sweeps her off her feet (without knowing that Sand considers her his girl) and marries her. Sand accepts the situation, wanting Betsy to be happy. However, on their first anniversary, she catches her husband dancing with a barroom floozy. As a result, Sand quarrels with McMasters and they flip a coin for the entire oilfield. Betsy leaves too, but returns when she learns that her husband has lost almost everything to Sand and needs her.\
Each man goes through booms and busts. Building on his renewed success as a wildcatter, McMasters moves to New York to expand into refineries and distribution, competing against former customer Harry Compton ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Lionel_Atwill"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Lionel Atwill}}). Seeking inside information about his rivals, he hires away Compton's adviser Karen Vanmeer ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Hedy_Lamarr"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Hedy Lamarr}}), who uses her social contacts and womanly charms to gather industry information.\
Meanwhile, Sand loses everything he has built up in South America to a revolution. When he meets McMasters at an oilmen's convention, the two finally reconcile, and Sand goes to work for his old friend. When he suspects that McMasters is carrying on an affair with Karen, he tries to save Betsy's marriage by offering to marry Karen. However, she deduces his motives and declines. When a miserable Betsy tries to commit suicide by taking sleeping pills, Sand decides that the only way to help her is to bankrupt McMasters. Sand loses his costly battle with his former friend and goes broke. It is only when he asks McMasters to give his wife a divorce that the married man finally comes to his senses. Later, McMasters is prosecuted by the government for violating the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Sherman_Antitrust_Act"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Sherman Antitrust Act}}\'a0and loses his business. In the end, poor, but happier, Sand and McMasters team up again, with the blissful Betsy looking on. Aldrich supplies them with equipment and the whole cycle begins again.\
Alvin York, a poor young farmer from the rural area near\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Pall_Mall,_Tennessee"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Pall Mall, Tennessee}}, lives a hardscrabble existence in a community whose poverty and isolation leave them with a lifestyle hardly different from people of a century earlier. He is an exceptional marksman, but a ne'er-do-well prone to drinking and fighting, which does not make things any easier for his long-suffering, widowed mother.\
Alvin's farm is on rocky land high in the mountains, which barely supports him and his siblings. He meets a sweet-natured local girl, Gracie Williams, and works night and day at strenuous odd jobs to accumulate the payment for a fertile "bottomland" farm so she'll marry him. The owner, Tomkins, gives Alvin sixty days to raise the purchase price. On the day the last payment is due, Alvin wins the final needed amount at a target-shooting contest, but discovers Tomkins has reneged and sold the farm to Alvin's romantic rival, Zeb Andrews, keeping all of the partial payments Alvin had made. Alvin drinks heavily and swears revenge.\
That night, en route to attack Tomkins and Andrews, the rifle Alvin is holding is struck by lightning, splitting the barrel in two and knocking him off his mule. Similar to\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Conversion_of_Paul_the_Apostle"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 the biblical conversion of Paul}}, York survives the lightning strike and undergoes a religious awakening when he joins a revival meeting at the nearby church, vowing never to get drunk or angry again. He makes amends with the men who cheated him out of the land, while Gracie points out that her love is tied to him and not the bottomland.\
When the U.S. enters\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/World_War_I"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 World War I}}\'a0and York is drafted into the army, he tries to avoid induction into the Army as a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Conscientious_objection"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 conscientious objector}}, but is denied since his church has no official standing. He reluctantly reports to\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Fort_Gordon"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Camp Gordon}}\'a0for\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Basic_training"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 basic training}}, where he is harassed because of his objector status, but his superiors eventually discover that he is a phenomenal marksman and decide to promote him to\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Corporal#United_States"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 corporal}}.\
York still wants nothing to do with the Army and killing. Major\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/G._Edward_Buxton_Jr."}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Buxton}}, his sympathetic commanding officer, tries to change York's mind, citing sacrifices made by others throughout the history of the United States. He gives York a leave to go home and think it over. He promises York a recommendation for his exemption as a conscientious objector if York remains unconvinced.\
While York is fasting and pondering, the wind blows his Bible open to the verse "Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's." York reports back for duty and tells his superiors that he can serve his country, despite not having everything figured out to his satisfaction, leaving the matter in\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/God"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 God}}'s hands.\
His unit is shipped out to Europe and participates in an attack during the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Meuse-Argonne_Offensive"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Meuse-Argonne Offensive}}\'a0on October 8, 1918. Pinned down by deadly machine gun fire, the lieutenant orders Sergeant Early to take some men and try to attack the machine gun nests from behind. York suddenly finds himself the last remaining unwounded\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Non-commissioned_officer"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 non-commissioned officer}}\'a0in the detachment, and is placed in command by Early.\
Seeing his comrades being shot down all around him, his self-doubt disappears. He works his way to a position flanking the main enemy trench and, as a sniper, fires individual rifle shots with such devastating effect that the Germans surrender. Then, York forces a captured officer at gunpoint to order the Germans still fighting in another section of the line to also surrender. He and the handful of other survivors end up with 132 prisoners. York becomes a national hero and is awarded the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Medal_of_Honor"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Medal of Honor}}. When Major Buxton asks him why he did what he did, York explains that he was trying to save the lives of his men.\
Arriving in New York City in early 1919, York receives a ticker tape parade and a key to the city. He is impressed with the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Waldorf-Astoria_hotel"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Waldorf-Astoria hotel}}\'a0and its indoor electricity. Congressman\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Cordell_Hull"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Cordell Hull}}\'a0guides him through the city and informs him that he has been offered opportunities to commercialize on his fame, all totaling around $250,000 (for context, $3.6 million today). York mentions the bottomland he wanted and Hull responds he could buy it with the money. York rejects the offers, however, saying that he was not proud of what he did in the war, but it had to be done, and he will not profit from his fame. He tells Hull he wants to go home. He returns to\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Tennessee"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Tennessee}}\'a0greeted by Gracie and his family. To his surprise, the people of his home state have bought him the bottomland farm he wanted and built him a house on the land.\
A doe gives birth to a fawn named Bambi, who will one day take over the position of Great Prince of the Forest, a title currently held by Bambi's father, who guards the woodland creatures from the dangers of hunters. The fawn is quickly befriended by an eager, energetic rabbit named\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Thumper_(Bambi)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Thumper}}, who helps to teach him to walk and speak. Bambi grows up very attached to his mother, with whom he spends most of his time. He soon makes other friends, including a young skunk named Flower and a female fawn named\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Faline"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Faline}}. Curious and inquisitive, Bambi frequently asks about the world around him and is cautioned about the dangers of life as a forest creature by his loving mother. One day out in a meadow, Bambi briefly sees The Great Prince but does not realize that he is his father. As the great prince wanders uphill, he discovers the human hunter named "Man" by all the animals is coming and rushes down to the meadow to get everyone to safety. Bambi is briefly separated from his mother during that scene but is escorted to her by the Great Prince as the three of them make it back in the forest just as Man fires his gun.\
During Bambi's first winter, he and Thumper play in the snow while Flower hibernates. One day his mother takes him along to find food, when Man shows up again. As they escape his mother is shot and killed by the hunter, leaving the little fawn mournful and alone. Taking pity on his abandoned son, the Great Prince leads Bambi home as he reveals to him that he is his father. Next year, Bambi has matured into a young stag, and his childhood friends have entered young adulthood as well. They are warned of "twitterpation" by Friend Owl and that they will eventually fall in love, although the trio view the concept of romance with scorn. However, Thumper and Flower soon both encounter their beautiful romantic counterparts and abandon their former thoughts on love. Bambi himself encounters Faline as a beautiful doe. However, their courtship is quickly interrupted and challenged by a belligerent older stag named Ronno, who attempts to force Faline away from Bambi. Bambi successfully manages to defeat Ronno in battle and earn the rights to the doe's affections.\
Bambi is awakened shortly afterward by the smell of smoke, he follows it and discovers it leads to a hunter camp. Bambi is warned by his father that Man has returned with more hunters. The two flee to safety, although Bambi is separated from Faline in the turmoil and searches for her along the way. He soon finds her cornered by Man's vicious hunting dogs, which he manages to ward off. Meanwhile, at the "Man's" camp their campfire, unattended, spreads into the forest, resulting in a wildfire from which the forest residents flee in fear. Bambi, his father, Faline, and the forest animals manage to reach shelter on a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Bank_(geography)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 riverbank}}. The following spring, Faline gives birth to twins under Bambi's watchful eye as the new Great Prince of the Forest.\
{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Kay_Miniver"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Kay Miniver}}\'a0({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Greer_Garson"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Greer Garson}}) and her family live a comfortable life at a house called "Starlings" in Belham, a fictional village outside London. The house has a large garden, with a private landing stage on the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/River_Thames"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 River Thames}}at which is moored a motorboat belonging to her devoted husband, Clem ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Walter_Pidgeon"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Walter Pidgeon}}), a successful architect. They have three children: the youngsters Toby ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Christopher_Severn"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Christopher Severn}}) and Judy ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Clare_Sandars"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Clare Sandars}}), and an older son, Vin ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Richard_Ney"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Richard Ney}}), a student at\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Oxford_University"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Oxford University}}. They have live-in staff: Gladys, the housemaid ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Brenda_Forbes"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Brenda Forbes}}), and Ada, the cook ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Marie_De_Becker"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Marie De Becker}}).\
As\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/World_War_II"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 World War II}}\'a0looms, Vin returns from the university and meets Carol Beldon ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Teresa_Wright"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Teresa Wright}}), granddaughter of Lady Beldon ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Dame_May_Whitty"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Dame May Whitty}}) from nearby Beldon Hall. Despite initial disagreements\'97mainly contrasting Vin's idealistic attitude to class differences with Carol's practical altruism\'97they fall in love. Vin proposes to Carol in front of his family at home, after his younger brother prods him to give a less romantic, but more honest, proposal. As the war comes closer to home, Vin feels he must "do his bit", and enlists in the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Royal_Air_Force"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Royal Air Force}}, qualifying as a fighter pilot. He is posted to a base near to his parents' home, and is able to signal his safe return from operations to his parents by "blipping" his engine briefly (rapidly open and closing the throttle, which results in short, sharp roars of sound) as he flies over the house. Together with other boat owners, Clem volunteers to take his motorboat, the\'a0
\f1\i Starling
\f0\i0 , to assist in the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Dunkirk evacuation}}.\
Early one morning, Kay, unable to sleep as Clem is still away, wanders down to the landing stage. She is startled to discover a wounded\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Nazi_Germany"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 German}}\'a0pilot ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Helmut_Dantine"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Helmut Dantine}}) hiding in her garden, and he takes her to the house at gunpoint. Demanding food and a coat, the pilot aggressively asserts that the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Third_Reich"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Third Reich}}\'a0will mercilessly overcome its enemies. She feeds him, calmly disarms him when he collapses, and then calls the police. Soon after, Clem returns home, exhausted, from Dunkirk.\
Lady Beldon visits Kay to try and convince her to talk Vin out of marrying Carol on account of her granddaughter's comparative youth at age eighteen. Kay reminds Her Ladyship that she, too, had been young \'97 sixteen, in fact \'97 when she married her late husband. Lady Beldon concedes defeat, and realizes that it would be futile to try to stop the marriage. Vin and Carol marry; Carol has now also become a Mrs Miniver, and they return from their honeymoon in\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Scotland"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Scotland}}. A key theme is that she knows Vin is likely to be killed in action, but the short love will fill her life. Later, Kay and her family take refuge in their\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Anderson_shelter"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Anderson shelter}}\'a0in the garden during an air raid, and attempt to keep their minds off the frightening bombing by reading\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Alice%27s_Adventures_in_Wonderland"}}{\fldrslt 
\f1\i \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Alice's Adventures in Wonderland}}, which Clem refers to as a "lovely story". They barely survive as a bomb destroys part of Starlings. The Minivers take the damage with nonchalance.\
At the annual village flower show, Lady Beldon silently disregards the judges' decision that her rose is the winner, instead announcing the rose entered by the local stationmaster, Mr. Ballard ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Henry_Travers"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Henry Travers}}), named the "Mrs. Miniver", as the winner, with her own Beldon Rose taking second prize. As air raid sirens sound, and the villagers take refuge in the cellars of Beldon Hall, Kay and Carol drive Vin to join his squadron. On their journey home, they witness fighter planes in a dogfight. For safety, Kay stops the car, and they see a German plane crash. Kay realizes Carol has been wounded by machine gun fire from the plane, and takes her back to Starlings. She dies a few minutes after they reach home. Kay is devastated. When Vin returns from battle, he already knows the terrible news: Ironically, he is the survivor, and she the one who died.\
The villagers assemble at the badly damaged church where their vicar affirms their determination in a powerful sermon:\
A solitary Lady Beldon stands in her family's church pew. Vin moves to stand alongside her, united in shared grief, as the members of the congregation rise and stoically sing "{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Onward,_Christian_Soldiers"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Onward, Christian Soldiers}}", while through a gaping hole in the bombed church roof can be seen flight after flight of RAF fighters in the V-for-Victory formation heading out to face the enemy.\
During the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Spanish Civil War}}, an American language teacher, Robert Jordan ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Gary_Cooper"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Gary Cooper}}), who lived in Spain during the pre-war period, fights in the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/International_Brigades"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 International Brigades}}\'a0against\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Francisco_Franco"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Francisco Franco}}'s forces. An experienced dynamiter, Jordan is ordered to travel behind enemy lines and destroy a critical bridge with the aid of a band of local anti-fascist\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Guerrillas"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 guerrillas}}. The bridge must be blown up to prevent enemy troops from traveling across it to respond to an upcoming offensive against the fascists.\
Jordan meets an old man, Anselmo, who is a guerrilla fighter who will serve as Jordan's liaison with the local guerrilla fighters. Anselmo leads Jordan to a group of Republican guerrillas who are led by a middle-aged man named Pablo. Jordan falls in love one of the guerrillas, a young woman named Mar\'eda. Mar\'eda's life was shattered by her parents' execution and her gang-rape at the hands of the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Falangism"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Falangists}}\'a0(part of the fascist coalition) at the outbreak of the war. Jordan has a strong sense of duty, which clashes with the unwillingness of the guerrilla leader Pablo to commit to helping with the bridge-blowing operation, as it would endanger himself and his band. At the same time, Jordan develops a new-found lust for life which arises from his love for Mar\'eda. Pablo's wife Pilar displaces Pablo as the group leader and pledges the allegiance of the guerrillas to Jordan's mission. However, when another band of anti-fascist guerrillas, led by El Sordo, is surrounded and killed in a desperate\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Last_stand"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 last stand}}, Pablo destroys Jordan's dynamite detonation equipment, hoping to prevent the bridge demolition and thereby avoid fascist reprisals on his camp. Later, Pablo regrets abandoning his comrades and returns to assist in the operation.\
However, the enemy, apprised of the coming offensive, has prepared to ambush the Republicans in force and it seems unlikely that blowing up the bridge will do much to prevent a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Rout"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 rout}}. Regardless, Jordan understands that he must still demolish the bridge in an attempt to prevent fascist reinforcements from overwhelming his allies. Lacking the equipment destroyed by Pablo, Jordan and Anselmo improvise an alternative method to explode the dynamite by using\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Hand_grenade"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 hand grenades}}. Jordan attaches wires to the grenades so that their pins can be pulled from a distance. This improvised plan is considerably more dangerous than using conventional detonators, because the men must increase their proximity to the explosion.\
While the guerrilla fighters\'97Pablo, Pilar, and Mar\'eda\'97create a diversion for Jordan and Anselmo, the two men plant and detonate the dynamite, costing Anselmo his life when he is hit by a piece of debris from the exploding bridge. While the guerrillas are escaping on horseback, Jordan is maimed when a fascist tank shoots his horse out from under him. Jordan cannot feel his legs and he knows that if his comrades stop to rescue him, they too will be captured or killed. He bids goodbye to Mar\'eda and ensures that she escapes to safety with the surviving guerrillas. Armed with a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Lewis_gun"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Lewis machine gun}}, he waits until the horse-mounted fascist soldiers appear in his gun sights. He then pulls the trigger, firing a sweeping barrage at the oncoming soldiers. The film ends with Jordan firing the Lewis gun directly at the camera.\
In World War I song-and-dance man Jerry Jones ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/George_Murphy"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 George Murphy}}) is drafted into the US Army, where he stages a revue called\'a0
\f1\i Yip Yip Yaphank.
\f0\i0 \'a0It is a rousing success, but one night during the show orders are received to leave immediately for France: instead of the finale, the troops march up the aisles through the audience, out the theater's main entrance and into a convoy of waiting trucks. Among the teary, last-minute goodbyes Jones kisses his newlywed bride Ethel ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Rosemary_DeCamp"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Rosemary DeCamp}}) farewell.\
In the trenches of France, several of the soldiers in the production are killed or wounded by shrapnel from a German artillery barrage. Jones is wounded in the leg and must walk with a cane, ending his career as a dancer. Nevertheless, he is resolved to find something useful to do, especially now that he is the father of a son. Sgt. McGee ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Alan_Hale,_Sr."}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Alan Hale, Sr.}}) and Pvt. Eddie Dibble ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Charles_Butterworth_(actor)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Charles Butterworth}}), the troop bugler, also survive.\
Twenty-five years later World War II is raging in Europe. Jerry's son Johnny ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Ronald_Reagan"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Ronald Reagan}}) enlists in the Army shortly after\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Pearl Harbor}}. He tells his sweetheart Eileen Dibble ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Joan_Leslie"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Joan Leslie}}) that they cannot marry until he returns, since he doesn't want to make her a widow.\
Johnny reluctantly accepts an order to stage another musical, following in his father's footsteps. The show goes on tour throughout the United States and eventually plays\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Washington,_D.C."}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Washington, D.C.}}, in front of\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 President Roosevelt}}(
\f2\b Jack Young
\f0\b0 ). During the show it is announced that this is the last performance: the soldiers in the production have been ordered back to their combat units.\
Eileen, who has joined the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Red_Cross"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Red Cross}}\'a0auxiliary, appears backstage. During a break in the show she brings a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Religious_minister"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 minister}}\'a0and convinces Johnny that they should marry now - which they do, in the alley behind the theater, with their fathers acting as witnesses.\
The plot provides an envelope to showcase both revues.\
Father Charles \'93Chuck\'94 O\'92Malley, an incoming priest from\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/East_St._Louis"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 East St. Louis}}, arrives in\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/New_York_City"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 New York City}}\'a0with an unconventional style that will transform the parish life of St. Dominic\'92s Church.\
On his first day, O'Malley gets into a series of mishaps; his informal appearance and attitude make a poor impression with the elder pastor, Father Fitzgibbon. The very traditional Fitzgibbon is further put off by O\'92Malley\'92s recreational habits\'a0\'96 particularly his golf-playing\'a0\'96 and his friendship with the even more casual Father Timmy O\'92Dowd. In a discussion between O'Malley and O'Dowd without Fitzgibbon present, it is revealed that O\'92Malley was sent by the bishop to take charge of the affairs of the parish, but that Fitzgibbon is to remain as pastor. To spare Fitzgibbon\'92s feelings, the older pastor is kept unaware of this arrangement and believes that O\'92Malley is simply his assistant.\
A series of events highlights the difference between O\'92Malley and Fitzgibbon\'92s styles, as they deal with events like a parishioner being evicted and a young woman named Carol James having run away from home. The most consequential difference of opinion between O\'92Malley and Fitzgibbon arises in their handling of the youth of the church, many of whom are consistently getting into trouble with the law in a gang led by Tony Scaponi. Fitzgibbon is inclined to look the other way, siding with the boys because of their frequent church attendance. O\'92Malley seeks to make inroads into the boys\'92 lives, befriending Scaponi and eventually convincing the boys to become a church choir.\
The noise of the practicing choir annoys Fitzgibbon, who finally decides to go to the bishop and ask for O\'92Malley to be transferred away. In the course of the conversation, Fitzgibbon infers the bishop\'92s intention to put O\'92Malley in charge of the parish. To avoid an uncomfortable situation, instead of making his initial request, Fitzgibbon asks the bishop to put O\'92Malley in charge, and then, resigned to his fate of losing control over the church, he informs O\'92Malley of his new role.\
A distressed Fitzgibbon then runs away, leading to a search. He returns late at night, and as O\'92Malley puts the older priest to bed, the two begin to bond. They discuss Fitzgibbon\'92s long-put-off desire to go to\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Ireland"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Ireland}}\'a0and see his mother, whom he has not seen since he left Ireland as a young priest to come to America, and who is now over 90. O\'92Malley puts Fitzgibbon to sleep with an Irish lullaby, \'93{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Too_Ra_Loo_Ra_Loo_Ral"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Too Ra Loo Ra Loo Ral}}\'94.\
O'Malley runs into Jenny Tuffel, an old girlfriend whom he left to join the priesthood. Jenny now has a successful career with the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Metropolitan_Opera"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Metropolitan Opera}}, performing under the stage name Genevieve Linden. As she prepares to go onstage as the lead in a performance of\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Carmen"}}{\fldrslt 
\f1\i \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Carmen}}, the two discuss their past, and she learns that her world travels with a previous opera company caused her to miss his letter explaining he had entered the priesthood.\
O'Malley next pays a visit to Carol, who is now suspected of living in sin with Ted Haines Jr., the son of the church's mortgage-holder, Ted Haines Sr. On this visit, O\'92Malley describes to the young couple his calling in life to \'93go his way,\'94 which to him means to follow after the joyous side of religion and lead others to do the same. He performs for them the song \'93Going My Way,\'94 which he wrote on this theme.\
Jenny visits O\'92Malley at the church, sees the boys\'92 choir, and reads the sheet music of \'93Going My Way.\'94 She, O'Malley, and Father O\'92Dowd devise a plan to rent out the Metropolitan, perform \'93Going My Way\'94 with the choir and a full orchestra, then sell the rights to the song, thereby saving the church from its financial woes. The plan fails, as the music executive brought on to hear the song does not believe it will sell. The choir decides to make the most of its opportunity on the grand stage, and sings another song, "{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Swinging_on_a_Star"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Swinging on a Star}}". The executive overhears the song and decides to buy it, providing enough money to pay off the church mortgage.\
With the church affairs in order, O\'92Malley and Fitzgibbon go on a golf course together. Just as everything seems to have fallen into place, though, the parish church is damaged in a massive fire. O'Malley prepares to move on to a new assignment from the bishop. He leaves O\'92Dowd to be Fitzgibbon\'92s new assistant, putting Tony Scaponi in charge of the choir. On Christmas Eve, parishioners gather in a temporary church for a service that also serves as O'Malley's farewell. As a going-away present, O\'92Malley has sent for Fitzgibbon\'92s mother from Ireland. As mother and son embrace for the first time in 45 years, the choir sings \'93Too-ra-loo-ra-loo-ral\'94, as Father O\'92Malley quietly slips away into the night.\
\pard\pardeftab720\sl280\sa240\partightenfactor0

\f1\i \cf2 Mom and Dad
\f0\i0 \'a0tells the story of Joan Blake ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/June_Carlson"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 June Carlson}}), a young girl who falls for the pilot Jack Griffin (Bob Lowell). After being sweet talked by Griffin, she has sex with him. The girl requests "{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Social_hygiene"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 hygiene books}}" from her mother Sarah Blake (Lois Austin); however, the mother refuses because the girl is not yet married. The girl later learns from her father Dan Blake (George Eldredge) that the pilot has died in a crash. She tears up a letter she had been writing to him, and lowers her head as the film fades into intermission.\
The film resumes at the point when the girl discovers that her clothes no longer fit, sending her into a state of despair. She takes advice from her teacher, Carl Blackburn (Hardie Albright), who had previously been fired for teaching sex education. Blackburn blames her mother for the problem, and accuses her of "neglect[ing] the sacred duty of telling their children the real truth." Only then is the girl able to confront her mother.
\fs20 \cf3 \super \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 [2][7]
\fs24 \cf2 \nosupersub \ulnone \strokec2 \
The film then presents reels and charts that include graphic images of the female anatomy and footage of live births \'96 one natural and one Caesarian. In some screenings, a second film was shown along with\'a0
\f1\i Mom and Dad
\f0\i0 , and contained images portraying\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Syphilis"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 syphilis}}\'a0and\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Venereal_disease"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 venereal disease}}.\'a0
\f1\i Mom and Dad
\f0\i0 \'a0is believed to have had a number of endings, although most typically concluded with the birth of the girl's child, sometimes\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Stillbirth"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 stillborn}}\'a0and other times put up for adoption.
\fs20 \cf3 \super \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 [7][8]
\fs24 \cf2 \nosupersub \ulnone \strokec2 \
The unconventional Father Charles "Chuck" O'Malley ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Bing_Crosby"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Bing Crosby}}) is assigned to St. Mary's parish, which includes a run-down inner-city school building on the verge of being condemned. O'Malley is to recommend whether or not the school should be closed and the children sent to another school with modern facilities; but the sisters feel that God will provide for them.\
They put their hopes in Horace P. Bogardus ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Henry_Travers"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Henry Travers}}), a businessman who has built a modern building next door to the school which they hope he will donate to them. Father O'Malley and the dedicated but stubborn Sister Superior, Mary Benedict ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Ingrid_Bergman"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Ingrid Bergman}}), both wish to save the school, but their different views and methods often lead to disagreements. One disagreement involves a student (Richard Tyler) who is being bullied by another. A more serious one regards the promotion of an eighth-grade student, Patsy ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Joan_Carroll"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Joan Carroll}}) of Syracuse NY, whom the parish has taken in while her mother ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Martha_Sleeper"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Martha Sleeper}}) attempts to get back on her feet.\
At one point, Sister Benedict contracts\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Tuberculosis"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 tuberculosis}}, and the physician recommends to Father O'Malley that she be transferred to a dry climate with non-parochial duties, but without telling her the reason. She assumes the transfer is because of her disagreements with O'Malley, and struggles to understand the reasons for the path set out for her. Right before Sister Benedict departs, Father O'Malley reveals the true reason for her temporary transfer.\
The film is set on a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Plantations_in_the_American_South"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 plantation}}\'a0in the southern\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/United_States"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 United States}}, specifically in the state of\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Georgia}}, some distance from\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Atlanta"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Atlanta}}. Although sometimes misinterpreted as taking place\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Antebellum_South"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 before the American Civil War}}\'a0while\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 slavery}}was still legal in the region, the film takes place during the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Reconstruction_Era"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Reconstruction Era}}\'a0after slavery was abolished.
\fs20 \cf3 \super \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 [5][6][7][8]
\fs24 \cf2 \nosupersub \ulnone \strokec2 \'a0Harris' original Uncle Remus stories were all set after the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/American_Civil_War"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 American Civil War}}\'a0and the abolition of slavery. Harris himself, born in 1848, was a racial reconciliation activist writer and journalist of the Reconstruction Era. The film makes several indirect references to the Reconstruction Era: clothing is in the newer\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/1870s_in_fashion"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 late-Victorian style}}; Uncle Remus is free to leave the plantation at will; black field hands are\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Sharecropper"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 sharecroppers}}, etc.
\fs20 \cf3 \super \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 [9]
\fs24 \cf2 \nosupersub \ulnone \strokec2 \
Seven-year-old Johnny ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Bobby_Driscoll"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Bobby Driscoll}}) is excited about what he believes to be a vacation at his grandmother's Georgia plantation with his parents, John Sr. (Erik Rolf) and Sally ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Ruth_Warrick"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Ruth Warrick}}). When they arrive at the plantation, he discovers that his parents will be living apart for a while, and he is to live at the plantation with his mother and grandmother (Lucile Watson) while his father returns to Atlanta to continue his controversial editorship in the city's newspaper. Johnny, distraught because of his father's departure, secretly sets off that night for Atlanta with only a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Bindle"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 bindle}}.\
As Johnny sneaks away from the plantation, he is attracted by the voice of\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Uncle_Remus"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Uncle Remus}}\'a0({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/James_Baskett"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 James Baskett}}) telling tales of a character named\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Br%27er_Rabbit"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Br'er Rabbit}}. By this time, word had gotten out that Johnny was missing, and some plantation residents are looking for him. Johnny evades being discovered, but Uncle Remus catches up with him. They befriend each other and Uncle Remus offers him some food for his journey, taking him back to his cabin. Back at the cabin, Uncle Remus tells Johnny the traditional African-American folktale, "{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Br%27er_Rabbit_Earns_a_Dollar_a_Minute"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Br'er Rabbit Earns a Dollar a Minute}}". In the story, Br'er Rabbit ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Johnny_Lee_(actor)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Johnny Lee}}) attempts to run away from home only to change his mind after an encounter with\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Br%27er_Fox_and_Br%27er_Bear"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Br'er Fox and Br'er Bear}}\'a0(James Baskett and\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Nick_Stewart"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Nick Stewart}}). Johnny takes the advice and changes his mind about leaving the plantation, letting Uncle Remus take him back to his mother.\
Johnny makes friends with Toby (Glenn Leedy), a young black boy who lives on the plantation, and Ginny Favers ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Luana_Patten"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Luana Patten}}), a poor white girl. Ginny gives Johnny a puppy after her two older brothers, Joe (Gene Holland) and Jake (George Nokes), threaten to drown it. Johnny's mother refuses to let him take care of the puppy, so he takes the dog to Uncle Remus. Uncle Remus takes the dog in and delights Johnny and his friends with\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Tar-Baby"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 the fable of Br'er Rabbit and the Tar-Baby}}, stressing that people shouldn't get involved with something they have no business with in the first place. Johnny heeds the advice of how Br'er Rabbit used\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Reverse_psychology"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 reverse psychology}}\'a0on Br'er Fox and begs the Favers Brothers not to tell their mother (Mary Field) about the dog. The reverse psychology works, and the boys go to speak with their mother. After being spanked, they realize that Johnny had fooled them. In an act of revenge, they tell Sally about the dog. She becomes upset that Johnny and Uncle Remus kept the dog despite her order (which was unknown to Uncle Remus). She instructs Uncle Remus not to tell any more stories to her son.\
Johnny's birthday arrives and Johnny picks up Ginny to take her to his party. On the way there, Joe and Jake push Ginny into a mud puddle. With her dress ruined, Ginny is unable to go to the party and runs off crying. Johnny begins fighting with the boys, but their fight is broken up by Uncle Remus, who scolds Joe and Jake. Johnny runs off to comfort Ginny. He explains that he does not want to go either, especially since his father will not be there. Uncle Remus discovers both dejected children and cheers them up by telling the story of\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/The_Laughing_Place"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Br'er Rabbit and his "Laughing Place"}}. When the three return to the plantation, Sally becomes angry at Johnny for missing his own birthday party, and tells Uncle Remus not to spend any more time with him. Saddened by the misunderstanding of his good intentions, Uncle Remus packs his bags and leaves for Atlanta. Johnny rushes to intercept him, but is attacked by a bull and seriously injured after taking a shortcut through a pasture. While Johnny hovers between life and death, his father returns. Johnny calls for Uncle Remus, who is then escorted in by his grandmother. Uncle Remus begins telling a tale of Br'er Rabbit and the Laughing Place, and the boy miraculously survives.\
Johnny, Ginny, and Toby are next seen skipping along and singing while Johnny's returned puppy runs alongside them. Uncle Remus is also in the vicinity and he is shocked when Br'er Rabbit and several of the other characters from his stories appear in front of them and interact with the children. Uncle Remus rushes to join the group, and they all skip away singing.\
After World War II, returning veterans Fred Derry, Homer Parrish, and Al Stephenson meet while flying home to Boone City. Fred is returning from Europe as a decorated captain and\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Bombardier_(air_force)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 bombardier}}\'a0from the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Eighth_Air_Force#World_War_II_(1944%E2%80%931945)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Eighth Air Force}}. Homer was a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Petty_officer_second_class"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 petty officer}}\'a0in the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/United_States_Seventh_Fleet"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Seventh Fleet}}\'a0when he lost both hands from burns suffered when his ship was sunk, and now uses mechanical hook\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Prostheses"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 prostheses}}. Al served with the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/25th_Infantry_Division_(United_States)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 25th Infantry}}\'a0as a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Platoon_sergeant"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 platoon sergeant}}\'a0in the Pacific. All three have trouble adjusting to civilian life.\
Al is a banker with a comfortable home and a loving family: wife Milly, adult daughter Peggy, and high school student son Rob. He is promoted to Vice President in charge of small loans, as the president views his military experience as valuable in dealing with other returning servicemen. When Al approves an unsecured loan to a young Navy veteran, the president advises him against making a habit of it. Later, at a banquet in his honor, a slightly inebriated Al expounds that the bank (and America) must stand with the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Veterans"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 vets}}\'a0and give them every chance to rebuild their lives.\
Fred, once an unskilled drugstore\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Soda_jerk"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 soda jerk}}, wants something better, but the tight postwar job market forces him to return to his old job. Fred had met Marie while in flight training and married her shortly afterward, before shipping out less than a month later. She became a nightclub waitress while Fred was overseas. Marie makes it clear she does not enjoy being married to a lowly soda jerk.\
Homer was a high school football quarterback and became engaged to his next door neighbor, Wilma, before joining the Navy. Homer and his parents now have trouble dealing with his disability. He does not want to burden Wilma with his handicap so he eventually pushes her away, although she still wants to marry him.\
Peggy meets Fred when picking up her father home from a bar where the three men had reunited. They are attracted to each other. Peggy dislikes Marie, and informs her parents she intends to end Fred's marriage, but they tell her that their own marriage overcame similar problems. Concerned, Al demands that Fred stop seeing his daughter. Fred agrees, but the friendship between the two men is strained.\
When an obnoxious customer, who claims that the war was fought against the wrong enemies, gets into a fight with Homer, Fred intervenes and knocks the man down \'96 costing him his job. Fred encourages Homer to put his misgivings behind him and marry Wilma, offering to be his best man.\
Wilma visits Homer and tells him that her parents want her to leave Boone City for an extended period to try to forget him. Homer bluntly demonstrates to her how hard life with him would be. When Wilma is undaunted, Homer reconsiders.\
Fred discovers his wife with another veteran. After complaining to Fred that she has "given up the best years of my life," Marie tells him that she is getting a divorce. Fred decides to leave town, and gives his father his medals and citations, including his\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Distinguished_Flying_Cross_(United_States)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Distinguished Flying Cross}}, with a citation signed by\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Jimmy_Doolittle"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 General Doolittle}}. At the airport, Fred books space on the first outbound aircraft, without regard for the destination. While waiting, he wanders into a vast\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Aircraft_boneyard"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 aircraft boneyard}}. Inside the nose of a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Boeing_B-17_Flying_Fortress"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 B-17}}, he relives the intense memories of combat. The boss of a work crew rouses him from his flashback. Fred persuades the man to hire him.\
People have gathered for the wedding of Homer and Wilma. Fred, now divorced, is Homer's best man. While the vows are exchanged, Fred and Peggy glance across at one another. At the conclusion everyone gathers around the newlyweds. Still gazing over at Peggy, Fred walks across the room, takes her in his arms and kisses her. He asks if she understands how things will be for them, that it could take years before they can get a life established. All the while Peggy smiles fondly at Fred, and then kisses him again.\
Pearl Chavez ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Jennifer_Jones"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Jennifer Jones}}) is orphaned after her father Scott Chavez ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Herbert_Marshall"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Herbert Marshall}}) kills her mother ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Tilly_Losch"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Tilly Losch}}), having caught her with a lover ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Sidney_Blackmer"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Sidney Blackmer}}). Before Scott Chavez is executed as a punishment for killing his wife, he arranges for his daughter Pearl to live with his second cousin and old sweetheart, Laura Belle ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Lillian_Gish"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Lillian Gish}}).\
Arriving by stagecoach, Pearl is met by Jesse McCanles ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Joseph_Cotten"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Joseph Cotten}}), one of Laura Belle's two grown sons. He takes her to Spanish Bit, their enormous cattle ranch. The gentle and gracious Laura Belle is happy to welcome her to their home, but not so her husband, the Senator Jackson McCanles ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Lionel_Barrymore"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Lionel Barrymore}}), who uses a wheelchair. He calls Pearl "a half-breed" and jealously despises Pearl's father.\
The second son, Lewt ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Gregory_Peck"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Gregory Peck}}), is a ladies' man with a personality quite unlike that of his gentlemanly brother Jesse. He expresses his interest in Pearl in direct terms and she takes a strong dislike to him. Laura Belle calls in Mr. Jubal Crabbe, the "Sinkiller" ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Walter_Huston"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Walter Huston}}), a gun-toting preacher, to counsel Pearl on how to avoid the evils of temptation. Pearl is determined to remain "a good girl."\
When she submits to Lewt's aggressive advances one night, Pearl is angry with him and ashamed of her own behavior. But she also cannot help but be flattered by his lust and attentions. Jesse, meanwhile, is ostracized by his father and no longer welcome at the ranch after siding with railroad men, headed by Mr. Langford ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Otto_Kruger"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Otto Kruger}}), against the Senator's personal interests. Jesse is in love with Pearl but he leaves for\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Austin"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Austin}}\'a0to pursue a political career and becomes engaged to Helen Langford ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Joan_Tetzel"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Joan Tetzel}}), Langford's daughter.\
Offended when Lewt reneges on a promise to marry her, Pearl takes up with Sam Pierce ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Charles_Bickford"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Charles Bickford}}), a neighboring rancher who is smitten with her. She does not love him but says yes to his proposal. Before they can be married, however, Lewt picks a fight with Pierce in a saloon and guns him down. He insists that Pearl can belong only to him. Lewt becomes a wanted man.\
On the run from the law, Lewt finds time to derail a train and occasionally drop by the ranch late at night and press his attentions on Pearl. She cannot resist her desire for him and lies for Lewt to the law, hiding him in her room. Afterward, however, he walks out on her, despite her pleas that she loves him.\
Laura Belle's health takes a turn for the worse and the Senator admits his love for her before she dies. Jesse returns to visit but is too late; his mother is dead. The Senator continues to shun him, as does Lewt, their family feud finally resulting in a showdown. Lewt tosses a gun to his unarmed brother but Jesse stands his ground without attempting to pick it up. Jesse warns that Lewt will eventually be hanged as a murderer, and Lewt responds by shooting Jesse.\
The Senator's old friend, Lem Smoot ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Harry_Carey_(actor)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Harry Carey}}) tells him that Jesse's wound is not mortal and the old man softens up towards his son. A livid Pearl is relieved that Jesse is going to survive. When Helen arrives, she invites Pearl to leave Spanish Bit forever and come live with them in\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Austin,_Texas"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Austin}}. Pearl agrees, but she is tipped off by one of the Spanish Bit hands, Sid ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Scott_McKay"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Scott McKay}}) that Lewt intends to come after Jesse again. She arms herself and engages in a shootout with Lewt in the desert, where they die in each other's arms.\
The film begins in 1644 during the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/English_Civil_War"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 English Civil War}}, as we see a group of\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Roundheads"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Roundheads}}\'a0pursuing a\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Cavalier"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Cavalier}}'s carriage. The carriage drives into the country where its passengers abandon a baby, named Amber, on the doorstep of a farming cottage. The roundheads soon catch up with the carriage and kill all the passengers while the farmers discover and decide to adopt Amber.\
The film moves forward to 1660; the death of\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Oliver_Cromwell"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Oliver Cromwell}}\'a0and the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Restoration_(England)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 restoration of the Monarchy}}\'a0.The residents of London rejoice and celebrate the return of the monarchy. However the small rural towns and villages remain strictly puritanical.\
Sixteen years after being abandoned in a small rural village, we see that Amber ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Linda_Darnell"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Linda Darnell}}) has grown into a beauty and is about to be married despite her protests. She wants to be more than a farmer's wife and dreams of court fashions and a life away from the village. Her dream comes true with the arrival of a group of cavaliers and the handsome Bruce Carlton ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Cornel_Wilde"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Cornel Wilde}}), with whom she becomes instantly smitten. She follows the Cavaliers to a tavern and begs Bruce to let her come with him to London. Despite her request and coaxing from Bruce's friend Almsbury ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Richard_Greene"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Richard Greene}}), Bruce refuses her, while Almsbury also unsuccessfully tries to seduce her. Amber once again tries to convince Bruce to take her to London, which he refuses, before they share a kiss.\
Bruce and Almsbury return to London to seek an audience with the king but are turned away.\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Barbara_Villiers"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Barbara Villiers}}, the king's mistress, is brought to court and coldly walks past them.\
As Bruce and Almsbury return to their London tavern, they see that Amber has followed them to London. Bruce allows her to stay with him and they begin an affair whereby Bruce pampers Amber with new gowns and takes her to the theater. At one performance, Bruce sees Barbara Villiers (Natalie Draper) alone and goes to speak with her about getting the king to grant him ships for his privateer mission. Amber is distraught at the thought of Bruce leaving and stops Almsbury from warning Bruce that the king has arrived. The king sees Bruce with his mistress and later summons him to court.\
Not wanting his friend to face the king's wrath alone, Almsbury goes with him. The king, however, grants Bruce the ships he needs and requests that he leave for Bristol that very night. Bruce and Almsbury return to the tavern to see Amber sleeping. Bruce plans on leaving before Amber wakes, and Almsbury helps him pack, despite telling Bruce that Amber loves him and it would be cruel.\
The next morning Amber wakes up to find Almsbury packing up his belongings and returning to Almsbury Hall. Almsbury explains that the king gave him back his lands and gave Bruce his ships as Amber races into Bruce's room to see it empty. Almsbury tries to convince Amber to go back to her village but she refuses, stating that she will marry Bruce no matter what. Almsbury leaves her and gives her money from Bruce to keep her from starving.\
However Amber is quickly conned out of her money, put in debt and sent to\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Newgate_Prison"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Newgate Prison}}. While in Newgate Prison, Amber discovers she's pregnant with Bruce's child and meets Black Jack Mallet, a highwayman, who falls in love with her and who helps her break out. The pair go to Mother Redcap's ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Anne_Revere"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Anne Revere}}) tavern where Amber gives birth to a son.\
Amber soon begins to make a living luring fops into alleyways where Black Jack robs them. During one of the robberies, Black Jack is killed by the king's guard and Amber flees. She hides inside a house where she is discovered by Captain Rex Morgan ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Glenn_Langan"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Glenn Langan}}).\
Captain Morgan gets her work as an actress to save her from being sent to\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Tyburn#Tyburn_gallows"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Tyburn}}\'a0and takes her as his mistress. While Amber is working as an actress, the Earl of Radcliffe shows an interest in Amber, and Almsbury returns to London. He is now married with a child and tells Amber that Bruce will return any day now. Captain Morgan also proposes to Amber but she rejects him because she still loves Bruce. She also turns down a chance to dine with Charles II because of Bruce.\
Bruce returns and Amber introduces him to their son, hoping he will want to settle down. However he wants to return to sea. Morgan finds Bruce and Amber together and challenges Bruce to a duel, saying Amber is his fiance. Bruce accepts though he tries to persuade Morgan to end the duel. Morgan refuses and Bruce winds up killing him. He blames Amber and rejects her, and leaves England.\
Amber decides to marry the elderly widowed Earl of Radcliffe. This will make her a countess, which she hopes will interest Bruce.\
She discovered that Bruce's ship has docked in London and he has fallen victim to the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Black_Plague"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Black Plague}}. She saves his life by killing a nurse and lancing a boil on his chest. Bruce recovers and after discovering Amber is married to Radcliffe, leaves Amber for Virginia.\
A great fire hits London. Charles II attempts to seduce Amber, but Radcliffe takes her home and locks her up in her room. The fire reaches their house, Amber fights with Radcliffe. A servant hits Radcliff and throws him into the fire, killing him. Amber becomes Charles' mistress.\
Bruce visits from Virginia with his new wife Corinna, wanting to take their son to America. Amber invites Corinna to dine with her and Charles II, hoping Charles will seduce her. Charles figures this out and allows Corinna to leave. Charles then ends his relationship with Amber, realising that she still loves Bruce.\
Bruce asks again for custody of his son. Amber asks the son to decide, expecting him to want to stay with his mother. However the son is keen to go to Virginia. Bruce offers Amber the chance to come with them but she decides to stay. Amber watches heartbroken as Bruce takes her son away.\
Based on Neil Swanson's\'a0
\f1\i Unconquered, a Novel of the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Pontiac_Conspiracy"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Pontiac Conspiracy}}
\f0\i0 , the film focuses on "Abby" Hale (Paulette Goddard), who is condemned to death by a British court, then offered clemency if she will become an\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Indentured_servant"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 indentured servant}}\'a0in America. There is a bidding competition between Captain Christopher Holden (Gary Cooper) and Martin Garth ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Howard_Da_Silva"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Howard Da Silva}}), which Holden wins. He then sets her free. Unfortunately, Garth is a sore loser; he kidnaps Abby and takes her to the western frontier, where he is involved in illegal arms sales to the Native Americans. Soon, Holden becomes involved in the conflict with the warring tribes and is reunited with Abby; he also has further confrontations with Garth and his henchman (Mike Mazurki).\
In 1912,\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Broadway_theatre"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Broadway}}\'a0star Don Hewes (Fred Astaire) is buying Easter presents for his sweetheart ("Happy Easter"). At one store, he must persuade a young boy to part with a cuddly Easter rabbit he wants and choose a set of drums ("Drum Crazy") instead. He takes the gifts to his dancing partner, Nadine Hale ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Ann_Miller"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Ann Miller}}), who explains that she has been offered a show that would feature her as a solo star. He tries to get her to change her mind and it looks as if he has succeeded ("It Only Happens When I Dance With You"), until his best friend, Johnny ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Peter_Lawford"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Peter Lawford}}), arrives. She reveals that she and Don are no longer a team and makes it obvious that she is attracted to Johnny. She continues to pursue him, but he refuses her out of respect for Don.\
Don drowns his sorrow at a bar, where he brags that he can make a star of the next dancer he meets. He picks one of the girls performing on stage, Hannah Brown ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Judy_Garland"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Judy Garland}}), and tells her to meet him for rehearsal the next day. He tries to turn her into a copy of Nadine, teaching her to dance the same way, buying her dresses in a similar style and giving her an "exotic" stage name, "Juanita". However, she makes several mistakes at their first performance ("Beautiful Faces Need Beautiful Clothes"), and the show is a fiasco.\
Hannah meets Johnny, who is instantly attracted to her and sings "A Fella With an Umbrella" while walking her to her rehearsal with Don. After he tries - unsuccessfully - to reunite Nadine and Don by inviting them to lunch and then leaving them alone, she tells him her friends are laughing because Hannah is trying to be her. He realizes his mistake and after hearing Hannah sing "I Love a Piano", he works out routines more suited to her personality. Now known as "Hannah & Hewes", they are shown much more successfully performing "I Love a Piano," "Snookie-Ookums", "The Ragtime Violin", and "When That Midnight Choo-Choo Leaves For Alabam'".\
At an audition for\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Ziegfeld_Follies"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Ziegfeld Follies}}, Hannah and Don meet Nadine, who will star in the show. Hannah realizes that Nadine was Don's former dancing partner and demands to know if they were in love. Later, Don meets Hannah back at the hotel and reveals that he turned down the Ziegfeld offer, believing that she and Nadine do not belong in the same show. Johnny arrives to take Hannah to dinner, at which he reveals that he has fallen in love with her. While she does like him, she admits she is actually in love with Don. They continue to have a close friendship.\
Nadine's show opens ("Shakin' The Blues Away") and Don is in the audience. When he and Hannah meet the next day, he reveals he signed them to star in their own show and invites her to celebrate over dinner. She arrives at his apartment, only to have him suggest a dance rehearsal. She is upset and tells him that he doesn't see her as a woman, only a dancing aid. She tries to leave, but he stops and kisses her. She then plays the piano and sings "It Only Happens When I Dance With You," after which he realizes he is in love with her and they embrace.\
The show contains a solo by Don ("{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Steppin%27_Out_with_My_Baby"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Steppin' Out with My Baby}}"), followed by the best-known musical number in the film ("{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/We%27re_a_Couple_of_Swells"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 We're a Couple of Swells}}"), in which he and Hannah play a pair of street urchins with vivid imaginations. They go to celebrate after the show at the roof garden where Nadine is performing. The audience gives them a rousing ovation as they arrive, much to Nadine's chagrin who hears the uproar backstage. After she dances in a number called "The Girl on the Magazine Cover," she insists that Don perform one of their old numbers with her for old times' sake - "It Only Happens When I Dance With You (Reprise)". When he reluctantly agrees, Hannah becomes upset and leaves, believing that he has only been using her to regain Nadine, and has succeeded.\
Hannah goes to the bar where she and Don first met. She pours out her troubles to Mike the bartender ("Better Luck Next Time"). When she returns to her apartment, she finds Don waiting. He tries to explain that he was forced to dance with Nadine and says he'll wait all night for her to forgive him, but just before she opens the door, he is evicted by the house detective. The next morning Hannah tells Johnny about her and Don's misunderstanding. He says if he loved someone he would let her know it. She realizes that he is right and goes to meet Don for their date at the\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Easter_parade"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Easter parade}}.\
Later that morning, several gifts arrive at Don's apartment, with no cards. Hannah arrives unexpectedly saying she sent them, oblivious to the previous evening's argument and urging him to prepare for their date. As they walk in the Easter parade, photographers take their picture, echoing the film's opening with Nadine, and he proposes to her ({\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Easter_Parade_(song)"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 "Easter Parade"}}).\
At a performance by the Ballet Lermontov at\'a0{\field{\*\fldinst{HYPERLINK "applewebdata://7998BC3A-FC84-49B5-A62D-C9951A11A103/wiki/Covent_Garden_Opera_House"}}{\fldrslt \cf3 \ul \ulc3 \strokec3 Covent Garden Opera House}}, music student Julian is in attendance to hear the ballet score\'a0
\f1\i Heart of Fire
\f0\i0 , composed by his teacher, Professor Palmer. Separately present is Victoria 'Vicky' Page, a young, unknown dancer from an aristocratic background, with her aunt, Lady Neston. As\'a0
\f1\i Heart of Fire
\f0\i0 \'a0progresses, Julian recognises the music as one of his own compositions.\
During the performance, Professor Palmer receives an invitation to an after-ballet party at Lady Neston's residence, also asking Boris Lermontov, the company impresario, to attend. Julian leaves the performance in disillusionment at his professor's plagiarism of his music. Lermontov and Vicki meet, and he invites her to a rehearsal of the company.\
Julian has written to Lermontov to explain the circumstances behind\'a0
\f1\i Heart of Fire
